yeah absolutely I think we closed our
first system in 20 is that correct 21
and 21 so we've been in uh in
Mississippi since 21. I've been buying a
number of water and waste War systems in
the state really as a company our
missions bring safe reliable and
environmentally sustainable Water
Resources to every community in the U.S
and every Community piece is really key
you know interesting the water and
wastewater business there's 85 000 Water
and Sewer Utilities in the country in a
place like England they're less than 26.
so it's a very fragmented market and
really as a company we're trying to
solve for the smaller systems that
typically don't have the technical
managerial or financial resources to
keep in compliance with modern EPA
requirements for health safety
reliability those kind of things we came
to state of Mississippi because
Mississippi has one of the highest
amounts of fragmentation so some of the
most small systems in the country and
one of the highest amounts of
non-compliance so they're a great number
of systems across the state they're not
meaning current health and safety
regulations so that's really what
brought us to the state
since we've been in the state we've
invested almost 40 million dollars in
property plant and equipment to improve
these systems and over the course of
that investment we've lost moving
towards three million dollars in cash
that's because the rates have existed at
the time of acquisition we're just not
sufficient to even cover basic operating
costs right so we've invest a lot in
this state I would say it's interesting
on the rate the rate comment 22 of the
systems we bought when we came to the
state of Mississippi had no rates so
some of them for decades were providing
some level of service now it's debatable
how good that was some was pretty bad
but weren't charging at all so that
that's a unique phenomenon I would say
in the entire country we've never
experienced that before State
Mississippi's first time we've had that
so since we've we've acquired these
systems we've embarked on a program to
fix them we kind of go through two
phases of investment the first is triage
we call that and the reason why I called
that is because these plants have an
original design so you've got a lagoon
system that's originally supposed to
have iteration and or you've got a
mechanical plant that's supposed to
treat have screening and aeration and
disinfection or you get a water system
where you've got hydronomic tank that
you know supposed to provide pressure
for a community kind of on and on well
when we buy these systems typically
they're in a complete state of disrepair
oftentimes they're completely failed
what I mean by that is mechanical
systems are not working the electrical
is not working or it poses a serious
health and safety hazard the pressure
tanks are leaking or not correctly tied
into the system I mean just kind of On
and On from there so we try and bring
those originally designed components
back into operation provide basic
service and then the next phase of
investment is we're bringing these
systems into final compliance so that
means for example there's a number of
Lagoon systems here in the state of
